image.altText: An artistic image showing the back of a police officer and a police car.

items.synopsis: Each year, dozens of people claim to have been injured by police, but only a handful of officers end up facing court for those alleged assaults. In South Australia, police have been accused of charging their alleged victims instead, to stop their allegations being properly investigated.

title.children: Alexander forgot his concession card on a train, a mistake which ended in his arrest and hospitalisation

image.altText: Two men drink champagne while standing at an office window.

items.synopsis: Sixty-six people earned more than $14 million in the 2020-21 financial year, but new data from the Australian Taxation Office shows they paid zero income tax.

title.children: 66 people earned an average of $14.5 million in 2020-21. None of them paid a cent in tax to the ATO

image.altText: A Ukrainian artist Olena Yanko paints sunflowers on cars which were destroyed by Russian attacks in Irpin.

items.synopsis: The war in Ukraine has not only destroyed infrastructure and claimed human lives, but the natural environment and wildlife have been decimated and could take decades to recover when the war finally ends.

title.children: The full extent of Ukraine's environmental damage isn't known, but what has been discovered already worries experts

image.altText: A woman in green and a man in blue standing on a driveway, with trees in the background.

items.synopsis: It's been two years after a powerful storm brought down trees across the Dandenong Ranges, east of Melbourne, many are still struggling to repair and rebuild from that night, and not a single home has been rebuilt.

title.children: Ben thought his 'forever home' was well insured, but the cost of rebuilding is beyond his family's means

image.altText: Brett Sutton looks to the side as he stands outdoors, in a shirt and jacket.

items.synopsis: Professor Sutton will join national science agency CSIRO after four years in the role as chief health officer.

title.children: Brett Sutton, who fronted Victoria's COVID response during pandemic, quits chief health officer role

image.altText: A close up of a gloved hand holding a ruby. A woman's face is blurred in the background.

items.synopsis: This is The Loop, your quick catch-up for this morning's stories as they happen.

title.children: World's largest ruby sets auction record, and can a robot dog be an art critic? Catch up with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The largest ruby in the world to come to auction has set a new record at Sotheby's New York, selling for $US34.8 million ($52 million). The ruby is known as Estrela de Fura 55.22, which means Star of Fura in Portuguese. "It is from Mozambique, which is also one of the new and more popular origins that we see for rubies, apart from the more traditional and the classic Burmese pieces," says Uni Kim, a jewelry specialist at Sotheby's Hong Kong. The ruby was found last July. "It is one of the biggest and largest gem-quality ruby that we have ever seen," Kim says. "The colour and the saturation, the clarity together with you know everything that comes together with the ruby, it's just a very fantastic and beautiful piece." The previous world record for a ruby sold at auction was set in May 2015 by a 25.59-carat Burmese stone called Sunrise Ruby that fetched $45 million at Sotheby's in Geneva.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: World's largest ruby sells at auction for a record price

props.alt: An Asian woman with white gloves holds a red ruby ring

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Victoria's Chief Health Officer Brett Sutton is stepping down from his position after four years in a role that saw him become one of the faces of the state's COVID-19 pandemic response. Sutton is leaving to take up a new position as Director of Health and Biosecurity at CSIRO. Sutton first joined the Department of Health in 2011, before being appointed chief health officer in 2019. Alongside Premier Daniel Andrews, he became a daily feature of Victoria’s COVID-19 response, delivering daily case numbers in televised media conferences. The 53-year-old Melbourne native spent a decade working in hospital emergency departments before stints overseas to Afghanistan and Ethiopia. You can keep reading this story here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Brett Sutton quits as Victoria's Chief Health Officer

featuredLink.title: Victoria's chief health officer Brett Sutton resigns after stint as face of COVID-19 response

props.alt: A silver-haired middle-aged man in blue blazer speaks at news conference

children.content: Brett Sutton with Premier Daniel Andrews in 2020
(AAP: Michael Dodge)

stepping down from his position
after four years in a role that saw him become one of the faces of the state's

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A Russian man has died after being mauled by a shark off one of Egypt's Red Sea resorts, Egyptian and Russian authorities say. Egypt's Environment Ministry says the man was killed after being attacked by a tiger shark in the waters near the city of Hurghada. A diver who arrived on the scene just after the attack said people had rushed to help the victim after a lifeguard from a nearby hotel raised the alarm, but were not able to reach him in time. Russia's TASS news agency said the person killed was a Russian man born in 1999 who lived in Egypt full-time and was not a tourist. The ministry says it caught the shark and examined it in a laboratory in an attempt to determine the reasons for the rare attack. Tiger sharks are a large species which reside in tropical and temperate waters, and are among sharks most cited by the International Shark Attack File for unprovoked attacks on humans.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Russian man dies after being mauled by a shark off Egypt's Red Sea coast

children.content: A Russian man has died after being mauled by a shark off one of Egypt's Red Sea resorts, Egyptian and Russian authorities say.

A diver who arrived on the scene just after the attack said people had rushed to help the victim after a lifeguard from a nearby hotel raised the alarm, but were not able to reach him in time.

image.altText: A stock market watcher stands in front of an ASX board.

items.synopsis: Tesla, Amazon and Apple boost US trade. Europe falls into a technical recession over the first three months of the year but another rate hike is expected. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX to follow Wall St tech rally, eurozone dips into recession

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In news that will surprise just about no one, especially if you're trying to get a loan at the moment, the 12 interest rate hikes by the Reserve Bank have had a massive impact on how much people can borrow. According to RateCity, the average family’s maximum borrowing capacity has shrunk by $247,700 compared to April last year, once the latest hike takes effect. The 'average' RateCity has used is a family of four, with one parent working full time, one working part time, on a combined annual income of $143,221 before tax — and that obviously doesn't account of individuals' particular circumstances. For a single person earning the average wage, with no debts, no dependents and minimal expenses, the maximum amount they can borrow from the bank will have dropped by $180,000 in the last 14 months. "People on the hunt for a new home have been dealing with a market that's defying gravity, on a budget that gets smaller by the month," said RateCity research director Sally Tindall. "Once this latest cash rate decision takes effect, the big banks' ongoing variable rates are likely to be over 6 per cent, which means borrowers will soon be stress tested at rates of over 9 per cent. " That's a staggering hurdle to clear, particularly for first home buyers with limited savings and smaller incomes. "If prices don't come down, potential first home buyers could end up sitting on the sidelines altogether, unless they can get a sizeable leg up from their family." It's also going to impact borrowers trying to refinance, as they'll be assessed on their ability to repay on the same stress-tested rates over 9 per cent — putting more people into the 'mortgage prisoner' camp, particularly those with newer or lower equity loans.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Borrowing power shrinks by nearly $250k: RateCity

For
a single person earning the average wage

"People on the hunt for a new home have been dealing with a market that's defying gravity, on a budget that gets smaller by the month," said RateCity research director Sally Tindall.

"Once this latest cash rate decision takes effect, the big banks' ongoing variable rates are likely to be over 6 per cent, which means borrowers will soon be stress tested at rates of over 9 per cent.
That's a staggering hurdle to clear, particularly for first home buyers
with limited savings and smaller incomes.
"If prices don't come down, potential first home buyers could end up sitting on the sidelines altogether, unless they can get a sizeable leg up from their family."

It's also going to impact borrowers trying to refinance, as they'll be assessed on their ability to repay on the same stress-tested rates over 9 per cent — putting more people into the 'mortgage prisoner' camp, particularly those with newer or lower equity loans.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's nearly tax time, but as you think about prepping your return you might be surprised to learn the following: 66 people earned more than $1 million and paid no income tax in 2020-21, according to newly released figures by the Australian Taxation Office (ATO). Analysis of ATO data by the Australia Institute shows those people earned an average of $14.5 million. One of the deductions they claimed was using a tax agent to manage their affairs, which is an allowable write-off — they paid on average a hefty $219,000 to their accountants. You can read the full piece from Kate Ainsworth here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The 66 millionaires who paid no income tax

featuredLink.title: 66 people earned an average of $14.5 million in 2020-21. None of them paid a cent in tax to the ATO

children.content: It's nearly tax time, but as you think about prepping your return you might be surprised to learn the following:
66 people earned more than $1 million and paid no income tax in 2020-21
, according to newly released figures by the Australian Taxation Office (ATO).
Analysis of ATO data by the Australia Institute shows those people earned an average of $14.5 million.
One of the deductions they claimed was using a tax agent to manage their affairs, which is an allowable write-off — they paid on average a hefty $219,000 to their accountants.
You can read the full piece from Kate Ainsworth here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning and happy Friday! Stephanie Chalmers here to take you through the day, and it's looking set to be a pretty positive start to the session with futures pointing higher. It follows some decent gains on Wall Street, particularly for tech stocks. Amazon rose 2.5%, while Netflix ended up 2.4%. Electric carmaker Tesla also did well, rising 4.6%. The US dollar came under some pressure as oil prices slumped, and some data on weekly jobless claims was worse than expected, which helped the Aussie dollar above 67 US cents. In Europe, markets were mostly higher but eurozone economic growth was revised lower for the first quarter, down 0.1 per cent. And since that's the second quarter of economic contraction in a row, that means a 'technical recession'. It's been a pretty massive week, with the Reserve Bank raising rates for a 12th time and Australia's economic growth slowing, so stick with us, ahead of what's a long weekend in some states (the ASX will be closed on Monday).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX eyes gains after Wall Street rallies

image.altText: Three men in forensic gear gather at playground.

items.synopsis: Four children, aged between 22-months and three-years-old, were injured in a knife attack in the French town of Annecy.

title.children: Four toddlers fighting for life after knife attack in France

image.altText: A young man on a road looks down at his watch. He is wearing workout gear. One knee is on the ground.

items.synopsis: Australians would be warned within minutes if they were falling sick under an ambitious new plan from scientists, who hope artificial intelligence will be the key to stopping the next pandemic or slowing the spread of weaponised diseases.

title.children: How wearable technology could become the first line of defence against biological warfare

image.altText: Men in suits with heads not visible.

items.synopsis: Research from the OECD shows businesses are the big beneficiaries of inflation so far, but the tables may be starting to turn.

title.children: Profits dominating inflation according to OECD research. But is it really that simple?

image.altText: Officials dressed in black carry boxes containing human remains.

items.synopsis: A delegation from New Zealand is in Germany tasked with repatriating more than 100 Māori and Moriori remains looted or traded during colonial times.

title.children: 'I apologise institutionally, but also as a human being': New Zealand ancestral remains returned after 150 years

image.altText: Silhouette of two people using laptops in front of the Facebook logo.

items.synopsis: Following the proposal of new anti-discrimination laws in Queensland, claims swirled online that it meant offensive posts on social media could lead to three years of jail. Is that correct?

title.children: Could 'offensive' social media posts really put you behind bars in Queensland?

image.altText: Julian Assange greets supporters outside the Ecuadorian embassy in London.

items.synopsis: Australian Julian Assange will fight to overturn a United Kingdom High Court ruling that rejected his appeal against extradition to the United States.

title.children: Julian Assange will fight UK High Court decision in last legal option against extradition to the US

image.altText: Fruit that looks like bananas and some plant cuttings laid out on a stainless steel bench.

items.synopsis: Plant cuttings disguised as botox, tea, and seafood have cost four travellers entering Australia $22,000 for biosecurity breaches.

title.children: Travellers fined thousands for trying to sneak plant cuttings into Australia

image.altText: People wait for fireworks at Sydney Harbour Bridge

items.synopsis: North Sydney Council's ballooning legal bill comes as a new report from the NSW Productivity Commission finds the city's most affluent suburbs must become higher and denser to arrest the housing crisis.

title.children: Sydney council spends millions blocking developments, as mayor at risk of losing her view

image.altText: A man with long, blonde, curly hair, poses and smiles at a camera, wearing a pattern shirt, standing in front of a window.

items.synopsis: Scott White was arrested in 2020 over Scott Johnson's death, decades after the then-27-year-old's body was found at the base of cliffs in Manly near a gay beat.

title.children: 'Our family has got some peace': Sydney cliff killer jailed decades after death of US mathematician

image.altText: A man holds a fish

items.synopsis: There are fears fresh fish prices could "go through the roof" with a ban on gillnet fishing, paving the way for more imported seafood.

title.children: Fish and chip prices to rise with ban on major form of fishing, a fisheries scientist says

image.altText: Cameron Green celebrates

items.synopsis: Australia has a lead of 318 runs after day two of the World Test Championship Final saw India reduced to 5-151, after Steve Smith's century helped Australia to 469 all out in their first innings.

title.children: Australia in control against India after another dominant performance

image.altText: Aryna Sabalenka and Alexander Lukashenko.

items.synopsis: Aryna Sabalenka is "not an expert in politics" and never has that been more apparent than when she denounced a war and an autocratic strongman with a history of revenge.

title.children: Europe's last dictator celebrated this young tennis star. Then Aryna Sabalenka publicly disowned him

image.altText: A Navy officer in camo fatigues uses binoculars to look from the side of his ship towards another boat across choppy grey water

items.synopsis: China says all of the South China Sea belongs to it and presses its claims with a huge deployment of coast guard and fishing boats as far as 1,500km off its coastline, while Indonesia says the planned exercise is about  strengthening "ASEAN centrality".

title.children: ASEAN to hold first joint military exercise off Indonesia as South China Sea tensions simmer

image.altText: A man wearing a blue and yellow polo and a dark cap leaning against a wall looking out to sea

items.synopsis: Torres Strait Islander elders continue the fight to protect their islands from disappearing in rising sea levels in week one of the Federal Court's on-country hearing.

title.children: 'We are part of Australia': Uncle Pabai's plea during climate court hearing

image.altText: A man sitting on a couch with a blue backdrop with the initials CBN.

items.synopsis: Pat Robertson, a religious broadcaster who turned a tiny Virginia TV station into the global Christian Broadcasting Network, ran for president and helped make religion central to Republican Party politics in America, has died at 93.

title.children: US religious broadcaster and former presidential candidate Pat Robertson dies aged 93

image.altText: A large crowd with people holding shields over some people exiting a car.

items.synopsis: The former Pakistani prime minister says he is facing nearly 150 charges, all of which he denies, since his initial May 9 arrest.

title.children: Imran Khan granted bail on new charges accusing him of link to murder

image.altText: A young woman with red lipstick smiles while hugging her grandmother

items.synopsis: Around one in three families has multiple generations living under the same roof. Cost of living could see that figure increase.

title.children: Young people are moving back in with their families — and it's not just them benefiting

image.altText: A man standing next to a metal fence on vacant land

items.synopsis: Victorians who have fallen through the cracks in the wake of the Porter Davis collapse are calling for the government to include them in a $15 million insurance scheme.

title.children: 'I can't walk away from $18,000': Collapsed home builder customers barred from compensation scheme

image.altText: Greg Jenkins holds a box with his mother's ashes at Adelaide Airport

items.synopsis: The family of an Adelaide woman who disappeared in Malaysia more than five years ago says the circumstances of her death will now be re-examined in court.

title.children: Family of woman whose remains were found in Malaysia says 'mum's case remains open'

image.altText: Cyril Rioli celebrates a Hawthorn goal

items.synopsis: Brisbane Lions coach Chris Fagan backs his relationship with Cyril Rioli, after the former Hawks star identified himself as one of the complainants in the Hawthorn investigation.

title.children: 'We had a great friendship': Fagan says his relationship with former Hawks star was 'positive'

image.altText: A A380 passenger plane with British Airways branding.

items.synopsis: The Cl0p ransomware syndicate announces on its dark web site that victims have until June 14 to negotiate a ransom or risk having sensitive stolen data dumped online.

title.children: BBC, British Airways among first big-name victims in global supply-chain hack

image.altText: A view from above of water surrounding houses.

items.synopsis: Nine people are injured by shelling and Ukraine says the average level of flooding in the Kherson region is 5.61 metres as authorities work to evacuate more people after the collapse of the Nova Kakhovka dam.

title.children: Russia shells Ukraine's Kherson as residents flee flood waters from destroyed dam

image.altText: Two Victoria Police vehicles on the road.

items.synopsis: Victoria Police has launched an operation targeting road safety after 142 people died on the state's roads for the year-to-date. That number is up by 35 per cent on last year's road toll for the same period.

title.children: Police 'astounded' by number of Victorians not wearing seatbelts as state's road toll soars

image.altText: A middle-aged man of Korean descent hands a stack of papers to another man behind a desk in an office building.

items.synopsis: The country's Truth and Reconciliation Commission has previously acknowledged the records of many adoptees sent to the West were manipulated and falsely described them as orphans, increasing their adoptability.

title.children: South Korean inquiry to investigate 237 more foreign adoptions suspected to be fraudulent

image.altText: Former prime minister Bob Hawke receives a bark painting from Galarrwuy Yunupingu in 1988.

items.synopsis: The Barunga Festival gets underway, marking 35 years since Indigenous leaders presented the Barunga Statement to former prime minister Bob Hawke. So, what's changed since then?

title.children: It's 35 years since Bob Hawke was presented with the Barunga Statement. What's changed?

image.altText: A middle-aged white man with grey hair and glasses wearing a suit speaks in a public place with a cityscape behind him.

items.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese faces questions on whether he coordinated with Brittany Higgins over her allegation of rape, which was never proven, and claims of a cover-up by the former government.

title.children: Anthony Albanese faces questions on whether he planned with Brittany Higgins to pursue Coalition

image.altText: a woman kneels next to a labrador dog

items.synopsis: A video of Janice Whittle and her service dog Keegan being asked to leave a Toowoomba hotel went viral this week. She says it's time everyone understood the importance of assistance dogs.

title.children: Woman with guide dog asked to leave hotel in viral video says service refusal still too common

image.altText: Ade wears a blue suit while sitting in a wheelchair

items.synopsis: Looking behind the glitz and glamour of Australia's media and entertainment industry, a report finds people with disabilities face discrimination, poor access and and a pay gap, but things are improving.

title.children: Ade hit rock bottom when he had a stroke, but now he helps others thrive in Australia's screen industry
